data.title: Python vs JavaScript vs C++ vs Java vs Go: Which is Best? - LinkedIn
data.snippet: Python is a popular programming language, but it‚Äôs not the only option out there. Here's a comparison between Python and some other common programming languages: 1. Python vs JavaScript Python: Easy to read and write; great for beginners. Widely used for web development, data analysis, machine learning, automation, and more. Interpreted language (runs directly from source code). Slower than compiled languages, but great for rapid development. Large library ecosystem (e.g., NumPy, TensorFlow). JavaScript: Mainly used for web development to create interactive front-end applications. Runs in the browser, so no setup required for basic usage. Also has server-side capabilities (Node.js). Great for real-time applications (e.g., chat apps, games). Asynchronous programming is a key feature [...] apps, games). Asynchronous programming is a key feature (event-driven). 2. Python vs C++ Python: High-level and abstracted, making it easier to write and maintain. Slower execution time compared to C++ due to being interpreted. Great for prototypes, scripting, and data manipulation. C++: Low-level programming language, providing greater control over hardware. Requires more code for memory management and pointers. Faster execution, making it ideal for performance-critical applications (e.g., video games, real-time systems). More complex syntax compared to Python. 3. Python vs Java Python: Simpler syntax, which makes it quicker to write code. Dynamic typing and interpreted. Suitable for quick prototyping and writing small to medium-sized applications. Java: Strongly typed and compiled, [...] applications. Java: Strongly typed and compiled, which leads to faster execution. More verbose syntax and less flexible compared to Python. Excellent for large-scale enterprise applications (e.g., Android apps, web applications). JVM-based, which means it can run on any platform that supports Java. 4. Python vs Go Python: Slower than Go due to being interpreted. Great for quick development with large ecosystems in machine learning and web development. Go (Golang): Compiled and much faster execution. Known for simplicity, concurrency support, and scalability (ideal for building distributed systems). Used for high-performance backend systems and cloud infrastructure. Summary: Python is great for rapid development, simplicity, and versatility, particularly in data science, machine learning,

# How is Python different from other programming languages like Java or C++?

Farihatul Maria

4 min read

¬∑

May 19, 2024

--

Python, Java, and C++ are all popular programming languages used for various purposes, but they have distinct characteristics and are suited for different types of development tasks. Here‚Äôs a detailed comparison of Python with Java and C++ across various aspects:

## 1. Syntax and Readability:

 Python: Known for its clean and concise syntax that emphasizes readability and simplicity. Python uses indentation to define code blocks and avoids unnecessary symbols or boilerplate code.

```
# Example: Hello World in Pythonprint("Hello, world!")
``` [...] ## 3. Performance and Execution:

 Python: Interpreted language with slower execution speed compared to compiled languages like C++ or Java. However, Python‚Äôs performance can be enhanced by using optimized libraries (e.g., NumPy, Cython).
 Java: Compiled language that runs on the Java Virtual Machine (JVM), offering good performance and portability. Java‚Äôs Just-In-Time (JIT) compilation can improve execution speed.
 C++: Compiled language with direct access to hardware and memory, providing high performance and efficiency. C++ is often used for system-level programming and performance-critical applications.

## 4. Ecosystem and Libraries: [...] ## 5. Use Cases and Domains:

 Python: Ideal for rapid prototyping, scripting, web development, data analysis, and machine learning due to its simplicity and readability.
 Java: Commonly used for enterprise applications, server-side development, Android app development, and large-scale systems due to its performance, robustness, and platform independence.
 C++: Preferred for systems programming, game development, embedded systems, real-time applications, and performance-critical software where efficiency and low-level control are essential.

## Example: Comparing Basic Operations

Here‚Äôs a simple comparison of basic operations in Python, Java, and C++:

 Python:

```
# Python: Adding two numbersa = 10b = 20result = a + bprint(result) # Output: 30
```

 Java:

# Python vs C++ Speed Comparison

## I ran the same code on both languages and here is the result.

Halim Shams

4 min read

¬∑

Aug 9, 2024

--

There have been a lot complains about the C++ programming language due to the fact that collages or universities should stop teaching C++ to their CS field students as it‚Äôs an old language and has no use and bla bla bla.

On the other hand, there have been programmers consistently recommending Python for the new programmers as it‚Äôs easy to learn, powerful, and in-demand, and so on and so forth.

So, in this article, I have tried to write the same code in both of these programming languages and ran it so that you see the entire comparison ‚Äî the code and speed ‚Äî between these two languages in one go. [...] Exclusive content for passionate programmers! Subscribe to our newsletter for latest in tech, tips, hacks, and advice that will transform your coding journey.

Alright, let‚Äôs reveal the result.

This is how much it took for C++ to reach 1000,000,000:

It took 21ms (milli seconds) let alone a second, 21 MILLI SECONDS for C++ to loop through one billion!

It will certainly be more confusing for the new programmer who have recently got into the programming industry, and heard that Python is the fastest programming language to start with which almost totally untrue.

While it‚Äôs true that Python has become a superhero as with Python you can do whatever you want, which means it‚Äôs a general-purpose programming language compared to C++.

data.title: Which programming language should I learn first?
data.snippet:
But if you had to pick one, which one should it be?

If you are looking for a quick overall winner, go with Python. (That's coming from someone who learned programming with C and still swears it's the best language to learn coding). If you are ready to test the waters, you can get your feet wet with a free Python course.

That said, no matter which language you start with, here is the most important thing to remember:

> Mastering the foundations of one language will enable you to more easily learn other languages down the road. [...] But what I can tell you is this: Once you get the hang of basic problem-solving and coding in one language, you will have the right foundation to learn many more languages down the road.

So, let's get into the pros and cons of three popular languages:

1. Python
2. JavaScript
3. Java

## Pros and Cons of Popular Programming Languages

I will dive into each language later, but to start, here‚Äôs a table breaking down the key differences between three popular languages:

## Python as your first Programming Language

Within the last several years, Python has replaced JavaScript as the world‚Äôs most popular programming language. Therefore most new learners probably gravitate towards Python as their first language. [...] The debate between Coca-Cola and Pepsi is alive and well. Everyone has their own personal preference, and there‚Äôs no ‚Äúobjectively correct‚Äù answer.

Similarly, when it comes to the best first programming language, individual preferences usually precede facts.

At the end of the day, human beings are different. Many successful developers might tell you to start with JavaScript, while tons of brilliant programmers swear by Python. Meanwhile, plenty others might advocate for Java, C++, or Ruby, just to name a few.

I‚Äôm not here to tell you which language is right for you ‚Äî although in this article I will share pros and cons for a few popular options, so you can make a more educated choice.

data.title: 5 Types of Programming Languages
data.snippet:
### 3. Object-oriented programming languages (OOP)

This type of language treats a program as a group of objects composed of data and program elements, known as attributes and methods. Objects can be reused within a program or in other programs. This makes it a popular language type for complex programs, as code is easier to reuse and scale. Some common object-oriented languages include:

 Java
 Python
 PHP
 C++
 Ruby

### Free Python tutorials

If you're teaching yourself Python but you're not yet ready to commit to an online course or program, you might consider bookmarking some of the following tutorials:

‚Ä¢ How to Use For Loops in Python: Step-By-Step

‚Ä¢ How to Use Python Break

‚Ä¢ How to Write and Use Python While Loops

‚Ä¢ Python Loops Cheat Sheet

### 4. Scripting languages [...] High-level languages, on the other hand, are less memory efficient but much more human-friendly. This programming style makes it easier to write, understand, maintain, and debug. Most popular programming languages in use today are considered high-level languages.

### 3. Interpreted vs. compiled languages

The distinction between interpreted and compiled languages has to do with how they convert high-level code and make it readable by a computer. With interpreted languages, code goes through a program called an interpreter, which reads and executes the code line by line. This tends to make these languages more flexible and platform independent.

Examples of interpreted languages include:

 Python
 JavaScript
 PHP
 Ruby [...] C and C++
 Java
 Pascal
 BASIC

C++ is a great programming language to learn if you're also interested in learning more about how computers function. While it may not be as readable as other high-level programming languages like Python, it can still be beginner-friendly. You can give it a try for free by enrolling in Codio's introductory online program, Programming in C++: A Hands-on Introduction Specialization. After a month, you'll have created and ran your first program in C++.

### 2. Functional programming languages
